Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The 2015 Taan Fiord landslide tsunami: An interdisciplinary study of cause & effect
Award.AbstractNarration:
As glaciers retreat, the ice pressing up against their valley walls disappears. These rock walls then become unstable and can collapse in catastrophic landslides. In Alaska, where this phenomenon is increasingly common, landslides sometimes fall directly into the ocean and trigger a tsunami. This is what happened in October 2015 in the Taan Fiord: the largest rock avalanche in America in decades plunged 150 million tons of debris into the head of the fiord, producing a wave of water that ran 150m up the opposite bank and scoured the forested flanks of the fiord for at least 12km. The goal of the project is to collect observations of this Taan landslide and tsunami, and to deliver a benchmark dataset to the science and engineering communities so that they can better prepare for future disasters.

The project will combine satellite images, field observations and ship-based mapping to constrain the dynamics of the landslide and tsunami, including the mass and velocity of debris when it struck the water, the magnitude of tsunami wave generation and its pattern of motion, and the submarine flow of debris and its deposition. Data collection will take place in the summer of 2016 and will be delivered to the community by the winter.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On October 17th, 2015, the an enormous landslide occurred at the head of Taan Fiord, an arm of Icy Bay in southeast Alaska. The landslide, the largest to occurr in North America in decades, triggered a tsunami that was detected on tide gauges over 400 km away. The landslide was initially detected using the global network of seismometers and a technique developed at LDEO/Columbia University.

Our project focused on understanding the effects of the landslide and tsunami through a combination of satellite, airborne and ground-based remote sensing, along with ground mapping, and numerical modeling.

The major goals of the project were to (1) study the subaerial landslide, including the source volume, and supraglacial debris sedimentology; (2) map the submarine landslide, including determination of the deposited volume and extent, flow patterns and any internal structures; (3) map the tsunami traces, including submarine and subaerial morphology, trimlines, etc; (4) map and sample tsunami deposits; (5) evaluate glacier response to the landslide impact; (6) evaluate fjord circulation and sedimentation response to landslide impacts; and (7) evaluate predictions made using the teleseismic method, including bulk mass, direction of motion, etc.

We found that the tsunami wave, at almost 200 meters tall was one of the largest in decades. We calculated that about 60 million cubic meters of rock moved during the landslide. We observed that most of the landslide is buried beneath remobilized fjord floor sediments.

We used the work to explore the sedimentological imprint of landslides and tsunamis in areas where a glacier is retreating. We developed new remote sensing techniques to examine the shape of the land before and after the landslide. Our work occurred very soon after the landslide event and sampled a fresh, recently disturbed landscape, observing how it quickly evolved after an extreme event. The data we collected will be useful for engineering studies, examining how trees were broken and bent after the tsunami wave went through. Our study characterizing how sediments moved in response to the landslide and tsunami can be used to help identify other tsunami deposits elsewhere.  We suspect more landslides will occur in newly deglaciated terrain (as occured in western Greenland in the summer of 2017) We worry about the impact of this sort of coupled landslide-tsunami would have had, had there been a cruise ship in the area. We are continuing to pursue understanding of the cascading hazards that this study observed.
